H0.text: Gravity converts solid matter into gases and light energy during the formation of stars.

H1.text: Gravity causes gases and dust particles to condense into spheres, best describing the role of gravity in the formation of stars.

H2.text: Gravity cools gases and liquids until they become one solid mass, which best describes the role of gravity in the formation of stars.

H3.text: Gravity pushes rocks and dust particles outward from a dense center.

A4.text: As the hydrogen lost energy through atomic or molecular energy transitions, the temperature of local clumps fell allowing more gravitational condensation.

A5.text: The initial star formation was driven by gravitational attraction of hydrogen within local areas of higher gravity called dark matter halos.
